sense.name: consider, believe, view
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] RECKON SCOMP NP1[agent] RECKON NP2[theme] as NP3[attribute] NP1[patient] RECKON TO NP2[theme] as NP3[attribute] (archaic)
sense.examples: Sean reckoned that, compared to the parser, the assembler was quick. Until a year ago, Sarah Dacre reckoned she had a blessed life. He reckoned she had disappeared, when she should have been brooding/feeding the chicks. He reckoned the sink as good a place as any to hatch some piece of boldness. Faith was reckoned to Abraham for righteousness.

sense.name: calculate, measure, measure out
sense.commentary: Syntax Includes: NP1[agent] RECKON NP2[theme] (as NP3[extent]) NP1[agent] RECKON ADJP[extent]
sense.examples: Stars are reckoned as so many degrees, minutes, and seconds from each other. Where specifically stated, a period or limit of time is to be reckoned. With that direction in mind, he reckoned the descent angle as sharp-1400 mils. The Queen is usually reckoned equal, in average situations, to two Rooks and a Pawn.

sense.name: have faith in, bet on
sense.examples: That evening he reckoned on Grushenka's coming almost as a certainty. Dante hoped from his poem the termination of his exile; he reckoned on Fame as his mediator. It is high time for reckoning on charter schools.

sense.name: settle accounts
sense.examples: Then hath the priest reckoned to him the money according to the years which are left.

sense.name: deal with, take account of
sense.commentary: Includes: RECKON WITH Note: often in the passive ("to be reckoned with")
sense.examples: Disability: a force to be reckoned. Reckoning with our own spiritual lives can be life-giving. With the failure to have reckoned with the past, the signs for the future are hard to ignore.
